title: Trigonometric Function - Modeling People in Line

content.question: The number of people waiting in a line to enter a stadium can be modeled by the function <math alttext="b"><mi>b</mi></math> defined by <math alttext="b open parentheses t close parentheses equals 42 cos open parentheses pi over 30 t close parentheses plus 45"><mi>b</mi><mfenced><mi>t</mi></mfenced><mo>=</mo><mn>42</mn><mi>cos</mi><mfenced><mrow><mfrac><mi>π</mi><mn>30</mn></mfrac><mi>t</mi></mrow></mfenced><mo>+</mo><mn>45</mn></math> for <math alttext="0 less or equal than t less or equal than 60"><mn>0</mn><mo>≤</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>≤</mo><mn>60</mn></math>, where <math alttext="t"><mi>t</mi></math> is the time, in minutes, since the stadium opened. Based on the graph of the model, which of the following is true?

choices.label: The number of people in line is never equal to <math alttext="0"><mn>0</mn></math> because the midline vertical shift is greater than the amplitude.
The number of people in line is never equal to <math alttext="0"><mn>0</mn></math> because the amplitude is greater than the midline vertical shift.
The number of people in line reaches <math alttext="0"><mn>0</mn></math> because the midline vertical shift is greater than the amplitude.
The number of people in line reaches <math alttext="0"><mn>0</mn></math> because the amplitude is greater than the midline vertical shift.

content.answer: The number of people in line is never equal to <math alttext="0"><mn>0</mn></math> because the midline vertical shift is greater than the amplitude.

topic.text: 3.7: Sinusoidal Function Context and Data Modeling

skill.text: Skill 3.C: Support conclusions or choices with a logical rationale or appropriate data.
